title: Liberalism in Ukraine
text:
This article gives an overview of liberalism in <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>. It is limited to <a href="liberalism">liberal</a> <a href="political%20party">parties</a> with substantial support, mainly proved by having had a representation in parliament. The sign ⇒ denotes another party in that scheme. For inclusion in this scheme, it is not necessary so that parties labeled themselves as a liberal party.
The Radical Democrats were one of the dominant forces in pre-revolutionary Russian Ukraine. Due to the splintered party system in <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>, the timeline is limited to the post-1990 period. The position of liberalism nowadays is unclear.
History.
In the mid-1990s, the <a href="Liberal%20Party%20of%20Ukraine">Liberal Party of Ukraine</a> ("Liberalna Partia", observer <a href="Liberal%20International">LI</a>) formed out of small parties in the <a href="Crimea">Crimea</a>. The <a href="Yulia%20Tymoshenko%20Electoral%20Bloc">Yulia Tymoshenko Electoral Bloc</a> ("Viborcyj Blok Julii Tymošenko") seemed to develop into a more or less liberal party. The <a href="Ukrainian%20Democratic%20Alliance%20for%20Reform">UDAR</a>, which as of 2013 holds 42 seats in the <a href="Verkhovna%20Rada">Verkhovna Rada</a>, has been described as a "Western-style liberal party". Other, small liberal parties include <a href="Liberal%20Democratic%20Party%20of%20Ukraine">Liberal Democratic Party of Ukraine</a>, <a href="Reforms%20and%20Order%20Party">Reforms and Order Party</a>, <a href="Pora">Pora</a> and <a href="Yabluko">Yabluko</a>. Also, the <a href="Democratic%20Party%20of%20Ukraine">Democratic Party of Ukraine</a> and the <a href="Democratic%20Union%20%28Ukraine%29">Democratic Union</a> have sometimes been referred as liberal parties, though their liberal nature has not been confirmed.
